raw.desc: Minimum level of aggregation. We assume that from this level, we need calculate the metrics at higher levels.Generally, the basic portfolio will be the level that the units will report. Additionally, for companies treated with a portfolio basis, the information reported to the Group will be at contract level.The aggregation levels for reporting are: client (for TOP list) and aggregation of basic portfolios (Group, Country, Unit, Entity, Business Line, Segment, Product, Forbearances, etc).The 'Sector' attribute is not consideres as mandatory but recommended.In case of changes in the definition of Basic Portfolio, some of its axis might happen to be considered as a new dimension. See functional document of Basic Porfolio's definition.In case of not having the data at the date requested, the last available data will be used.Concerning Structural Risks, 'Basic Portfolio' allows the segregation of 'Net REC' into 'Sovereign Risk Open_date' and 'Intragroup Risk Open_date'.

raw.desc: Subjective NPL, is a subjective classification of the risks (assets & contingent liabilities). In these cases, while the loan may only be impaired or even current in payment, there are reasonable doubts as to whether the customer will make full payment of the capital and interest under the contractual terms. These customers are assessed on a case-by-case basis using the expert criteria of the analyst/manager, and are considered by a decision-making body (in accordance with the Credit Risk Management Policy Manual).Classification as subjective NPL affects all the customer's transactions In the terminology of Bank of Spain Circular 4/04, this relates to 'Doubtful for reasons other than counterparty arrears'.

raw.desc: Weighted average maturity of the remaining amount of the cash flows that the borrower is contractually obliged to pay during the period. It is calculated using the following formula:M=MAX (MIN{?t{t*CFt/?tCF_t)This is calculated for each contract, and then in order to obtain the average, it must be weighted by economic EAD.It differs from the C.GGS.CP.00295 measure (REGULATORY MATURITY), in that neither maximum nor minimum amounts are applied. Also, the economic EAD is used instead of regulatory EAD.

raw.desc: New Production: This will comprise the new transactions and renewals with changes to terms and conditions not caused by financial difficulties arranged since a particular date, normally from the beginning of the month in progress, until a specific date. All the gross transactions will be taken into consideration, without taking into account the repayments on these transactions or renewals. Forbearance transactions are not classified as new production.In the reports, it will comprise the new transactions and renewals with increased limits arranged since 1 January of the year in progress until the date on which the report is produced.For Standardised Risks, new production will comprise the transactions arising from the decision events, Acceptance Pre-Approved and Acceptance Not Pre-Approved, formalised in the budget period.In the senior management report, if the information is presented on a quarterly basis, the New Production of the corresponding three months will be shown, without taking the previous three months into account. If it is the first or second month of the quarter, the information for one or two months, respectively, will be shown, without taking the new production of the previous quarters into account. For example, in the case of June, the first quarter will comprise the New Production for January, February and March, and the second quarter will comprise the New Production for April, May and June, without taking the New Production of the previous quarter into account.Stock: This comprises all the transactions with balances not yet paid, because either they have not yet reached their maturity date or, having done so, there are still payment obligations that have not been met, except the transactions arranged as new production. Therefore, all transactions made on the stock will be included in this section. Forbearance transactions will be included.Total Portfolio: it will include all the transactions defined for each metric independently of its credit status.Amortization of New Production: This will comprise those transactions from New Production which have been either totally or partially amortized during the current period.In the reports, it will comprise the amortizations formalized from the 1st of January of the current year up to the date in which the report is made.

raw.desc: Up to date: This is a classification of customer default risk established by the Bank of Spain in its Circular 4/04. It is defined as the balance of the debt instruments and contingent liabilities that do not meet the requirements to be classified in the following categories: substandard, doubtful due to counterparty arrears, doubtful for reasons other than counterparty arrears, or write-offs.Within this category, it will be necessary to identify the transactions that require special monitoring, which are understood to be those presenting weaknesses which, while not requiring higher coverage than those established for the standard risk transactions, make special monitoring by the entity advisable. The transactions that must be identified as under special monitoring will include, until their extinction, the following:- refinancing, refinanced or restructured transactions; - as well as those relating to customers declared to be in insolvency proceedings that have been reclassified from one of the doubtful loan categories as they met the requirements set forth therein; and- the transactions classified as standard of customers that have one or more transactions classified as doubtful due to counterparty arrears. Despite the foregoing, the refinancing, refinanced and restructured transactions will cease to be identified as under special monitoring when it has finished. This will occur after an exhaustive review of their equity and financial situation, where the holders will not foreseeably be in financial difficulty and, therefore, may meet the payment of the debt (principal and interest) of all their transactions at the entity in due time and form and, moreover, provided that they have settled the principal and interest payments accrued from the date on which the restructuring or refinancing transaction was arranged, where at least two years have elapsed since that date, where the principal of the transaction has been reduced by, at least, 20%, and where the customers have paid all the amounts (principal and interest) that were unpaid at the date of the restructuring or refinancing transaction.The Special Watch classification is a regulatory requirement and is a different concept to the Special Monitoring portfolios (see definition of FEVE contained in this document). Substandard Risk: This is a classification of customer default risk established by the Bank of Spain in its Circular 4/04. It is defined as the balance of the debt instruments and contingent liabilities that, while not meeting the criteria to be classified individually as doubtful or as write-offs, present weaknesses that may cause the entity to assume losses exceeding the coverage for impairment of the risks under special monitoring. This category includes: the transactions of customers forming part of groups in difficulties, for which overall losses are estimated that exceed those relating to the categories described in the foregoing points, and transactions not documented adequately.Furthermore, in accordance with the Corporate Policy for Debt Forbearance, the following would be classified as substandard:- Transactions classified as doubtful may be reclassified to substandard once three months of payment have elapsed (not including grace periods), provided that, during the period of the new payments of the transaction, all the amounts (principal and ordinary interest) that were unpaid at the date of forbearance are paid, and that there is reasonable certainty that the customer is able to meet the payments according to the repayment schedule.- If a grace period has been established, the forbearance will be reclassified as substandard risk, provided that it has not already been classified as doubtful risk. This classification must continue until three monthly payments (or equivalent) have been paid after the grace period has finished.- If a forbearance transaction becomes impaired, this will be regarded as sufficient cause to classify it as substandard risk:o Where, after the forbearance, a non-technical impairment situation arises, it will be classified as substandard risk, provided that this impairment denotes an overstatement of the estimated payment capacity on analysing the viability of the forbearance.o A situation may not be considered to be technically impaired where the customer continues in an impairment situation for more than 30 days or where the impaired amount is higher than a repayment amount.DNPA: DNPA meaning 'Doubtful, Not Pre-Action', is a subjective classification of the risks. In these cases, while the loan may only be in arrears or even current in payment, there are reasonable doubts as to whether the customer will make full payment of the capital and interest under the contractual terms. These customers are assessed on a case-by-case basis using the expert criteria of the analyst/manager, and are considered by a decision-making body (in accordance with the Credit Risk Management Policy Manual).Classification as DNPA affects all the customer's transactions Simple Default: This is the balance of transactions with amounts more than 90 days past due, unless they have been classified as written-off. Where there are stricter local criteria at certain Units, the more conservative criteria will be included for transactions in arrears.In the terminology of Bank of Spain Circular 4/04, this relates to 'Doubtful due to counterparty arrears', except that which is classified as Pre-Action Portfolio or Portfolio at Procedural Stage (see definition in this document). The sum of Simple Default and the positions in Pre-Action Portfolio and Portfolio at Procedural Stage is the total Doubtful Due to Counterparty Arrears (according to the Bank of Spain definition)Pre-Action: This category contains the positions of customers about whom there are sufficient doubts as to the possibility of repayment. This is normally the situation prior to initiating legal action.Procedural: In this situation, a court claim is made on the debt. The out-of-court process is managed with the customer by the Recovery Manager and/or through the lawyer representing us. The portfolio at procedural stage should also take into consideration customers in bankruptcy proceedings. This circumstance should not entail abandoning direct negotiations with the debtor. Therefore, the Portfolio at Procedural Stage will only include the balances of loans claimed using legal action that are not current in payment and that are non-performing. The other balances of transactions claimed using legal action that are current in payment will be included in the DNPA PortfolioWrite-offs: The balance of the customers written off or down according to the timetable (pursuant to the regulator's rules) or as a result of an internal decision where appropriate, which have been derecognised. Classification in this category does not imply that the entity will interrupt negotiations and legal actions to recover the amount owedTotal Portfolio: It will include all the transactions defined for each measure, regardless of their credit situation.

raw.desc: Up to date: This is a classification of customer default risk established by the Bank of Spain in its Circular 4/04. It is defined as the balance of the debt instruments and contingent liabilities that do not meet the requirements to be classified in the following categories: substandard, doubtful due to counterparty arrears, doubtful for reasons other than counterparty arrears, or write-offs.Within this category, it will be necessary to identify the transactions that require special monitoring, which are understood to be those presenting weaknesses which, while not requiring higher coverage than those established for the standard risk transactions, make special monitoring by the entity advisable. The transactions that must be identified as under special monitoring will include, until their extinction, the following:- refinancing, refinanced or restructured transactions; - as well as those relating to customers declared to be in insolvency proceedings that have been reclassified from one of the doubtful loan categories as they met the requirements set forth therein; and- the transactions classified as standard of customers that have one or more transactions classified as doubtful due to counterparty arrears. Despite the foregoing, the refinancing, refinanced and restructured transactions will cease to be identified as under special monitoring when it has finished. This will occur after an exhaustive review of their equity and financial situation, where the holders will not foreseeably be in financial difficulty and, therefore, may meet the payment of the debt (principal and interest) of all their transactions at the entity in due time and form and, moreover, provided that they have settled the principal and interest payments accrued from the date on which the restructuring or refinancing transaction was arranged, where at least two years have elapsed since that date, where the principal of the transaction has been reduced by, at least, 20%, and where the customers have paid all the amounts (principal and interest) that were unpaid at the date of the restructuring or refinancing transaction.The Special Watch classification is a regulatory requirement and is a different concept to the Special Monitoring portfolios (see definition of FEVE contained in this document). Substandard Risk: This is a classification of customer default risk established by the Bank of Spain in its Circular 4/04. It is defined as the balance of the debt instruments and contingent liabilities that, while not meeting the criteria to be classified individually as doubtful or as write-offs, present weaknesses that may cause the entity to assume losses exceeding the coverage for impairment of the risks under special monitoring. This category includes: the transactions of customers forming part of groups in difficulties, for which overall losses are estimated that exceed those relating to the categories described in the foregoing points, and transactions not documented adequately.Furthermore, in accordance with the Corporate Policy for Debt Forbearance, the following would be classified as substandard:- Transactions classified as doubtful may be reclassified to substandard once three months of payment have elapsed (not including grace periods), provided that, during the period of the new payments of the transaction, all the amounts (principal and ordinary interest) that were unpaid at the date of forbearance are paid, and that there is reasonable certainty that the customer is able to meet the payments according to the repayment schedule.- If a grace period has been established, the forbearance will be reclassified as substandard risk, provided that it has not already been classified as doubtful risk. This classification must continue until three monthly payments (or equivalent) have been paid after the grace period has finished.- If a forbearance transaction becomes impaired, this will be regarded as sufficient cause to classify it as substandard risk:o Where, after the forbearance, a non-technical impairment situation arises, it will be classified as substandard risk, provided that this impairment denotes an overstatement of the estimated payment capacity on analysing the viability of the forbearance.o A situation may not be considered to be technically impaired where the customer continues in an impairment situation for more than 30 days or where the impaired amount is higher than a repayment amount.DNPA: DNPA meaning 'Doubtful, Not Pre-Action', is a subjective classification of the risks. In these cases, while the loan may only be in arrears or even current in payment, there are reasonable doubts as to whether the customer will make full payment of the capital and interest under the contractual terms. These customers are assessed on a case-by-case basis using the expert criteria of the analyst/manager, and are considered by a decision-making body (in accordance with the Credit Risk Management Policy Manual).Classification as DNPA affects all the customer's transactions Simple Default: This is the balance of transactions with amounts more than 90 days past due, unless they have been classified as written-off. Where there are stricter local criteria at certain Units, the more conservative criteria will be included for transactions in arrears.In the terminology of Bank of Spain Circular 4/04, this relates to 'Doubtful due to counterparty arrears', except that which is classified as Pre-Action Portfolio or Portfolio at Procedural Stage (see definition in this document). The sum of Simple Default and the positions in Pre-Action Portfolio and Portfolio at Procedural Stage is the total Doubtful Due to Counterparty Arrears (according to the Bank of Spain definition)Pre-Action: This category contains the positions of customers about whom there are sufficient doubts as to the possibility of repayment. This is normally the situation prior to initiating legal action.Procedural: In this situation, a court claim is made on the debt. The out-of-court process is managed with the customer by the Recovery Manager and/or through the lawyer representing us. The portfolio at procedural stage should also take into consideration customers in bankruptcy proceedings. This circumstance should not entail abandoning direct negotiations with the debtor. Therefore, the Portfolio at Procedural Stage will only include the balances of loans claimed using legal action that are not current in payment and that are non-performing. The other balances of transactions claimed using legal action that are current in payment will be included in the DNPA PortfolioWrite-offs: The balance of the customers written off or down according to the timetable (pursuant to the regulator's rules) or as a result of an internal decision where appropriate, which have been derecognised. Classification in this category does not imply that the entity will interrupt negotiations and legal actions to recover the amount owedTotal Portfolio: It will include all the transactions defined for each measure, regardless of their credit situation.

raw.desc: Based on WD1 reporting Arrears bands (UTD, 1-30, 31-60 , 61-90, 91-120, 121-150, 151-180, >180)
raw.formula: From Source SanUK: missingFrom Source ACM: missingFrom Source AL:  if (CCB.AL.BO:Arrears_FINAL begins '0-30') then '1-30' else if (CCB.AL.BO:Arrears_FINAL begins '30-60') then '31-60'; else if (CCB.AL.BO:Arrears_FINAL begins '60-90') then '61-90'; else if (CCB.AL.BO:Arrears_FINAL begins '90-120') then '91-120'; else if (CCB.AL.BO:Arrears_FINAL begins '120-150') then '121-150'; else if (CCB.AL.BO:Arrears_FINAL begins '150-180') then '151-180'; else if (CCB.AL.BO:Arrears_FINAL begins '180+') then '>180'; else if (CCB.AL.BO:Arrears_FINAL begins 'UTD') then 'UTD'; else CCB.AL.BO:Arrears_FINAL;From Source AL_SWAPS: per ALFrom Source SanBB:  if (CCB.BB:Written_Off_Amount is not null) then 'WO' else if (CCB.BB:ConDaysExc_01 >= 1 and CCB.BB:ConDaysExc_01 <= 30) then '1-30' else if (CCB.BB:ConDaysExc_01 >= 31 and CCB.BB:ConDaysExc_01 <= 60) then '31-60' else if (CCB.BB:ConDaysExc_01 >= 61 and CCB.BB:ConDaysExc_01 <= 90) then '61-90' else if (CCB.BB:ConDaysExc_01 >= 91 and CCB.BB:ConDaysExc_01 <= 120) then '91-120' else if (CCB.BB:ConDaysExc_01 >= 121 and CCB.BB:ConDaysExc_01 <= 150) then '121-150' else if (CCB.BB:ConDaysExc_01 >= 151 and CCB.BB:ConDaysExc_01 <= 180) then '151-180' else if (CCB.BB:ConDaysExc_01 > 180 then '>180' else 'UTD'From Source SIF: missingFrom Source RP:  if (Src.Partenon.lending_account:ACCOUNT_MONTHS_IN_ARR = 0) then 'UTD'; else if (Src.Partenon.lending_account:ACCOUNT_MONTHS_IN_ARR = 1) then '1-30'; else if (Src.Partenon.lending_account:ACCOUNT_MONTHS_IN_ARR = 2) then '31-60'; else if (Src.Partenon.lending_account:ACCOUNT_MONTHS_IN_ARR = 3) then '61-90'; else if (Src.Partenon.lending_account:ACCOUNT_MONTHS_IN_ARR = 4) then '91-120';  else if (Src.Partenon.lending_account:ACCOUNT_MONTHS_IN_ARR = 5) then '121-150'; else if (Src.Partenon.lending_account:ACCOUNT_MONTHS_IN_ARR = 6) then '151-180'; else if (Src.Partenon.lending_account:ACCOUNT_MONTHS_IN_ARR > 6) then '>180';From Source UFSS: missing    when ConDaysExc_01 >= 121 and ConDaysExc_01 <= 150 then '121-150'    when ConDaysExc_01 >= 151 and ConDaysExc_01 <= 180 then '151-180'    when ConDaysExc_01 > 180 then '>180'    else 'UTD'

raw.formula: Derived from risk_reporting_group thus: case when Risk_Reporting_Group     in ('Aviation', 'Infrastructure Exit', 'Mitre', 'Property Exit'      , 'Shipping', 'Structured Finance','Syndicated Exit') then 'PBU'    when Risk_Reporting_Group in ('SanBB','Business Banking','NA to BB','BC to BB - PERF') then 'Business Banking'    when Risk_Reporting_Group in ('CAF','SAF') then 'SAF'    /*when Risk_Reporting_Group in ('CAF','SAF','SIF') then 'SIF SAF'*/    /*when PrePMA_Risk_Reporting_Group = 'Regional - Property' then 'Regional Commercial Mortgages'*/    when Risk_Reporting_Group = 'SBB Commercial Mortgages' then 'Secured Lending (SBB)'    when Risk_Reporting_Group like 'Business Centres%' then 'Business Centres'    when Risk_Reporting_Group like 'Business Banking%' then 'Business Banking'     else Risk_Reporting_Group end

Derived by several calculations from LastParent, Nivel2, instrument name, and other fields.  Generally, to find New_20F_counterparty_type, LastParent is matched against specific strings and occasionally NIvel2 or instrument name are also checked.   This, plus NEW_20F_Sub_Category, mostly determine the F20_Area.  NEW_20F_Sub_Category is determined by a large number of checks -- the condition that produces 'Structured Repos', the value relevant for Landing, is determined by finding an entry in the CreditNetting dataset.  Division, Reporting_Division etc are checked in other cases.

The 'recop' and 'recneto' fields are used, respectively; these fieldsare available in different timebands from 1w to 10y.For loans, the timeband corresponding to maturity is used.  For other products, a band is chosen by looking in the ReinounidoNet...eom file.  Here a max timeband for each ultimate parent is chosen.

terms.name: Last Statement Date
terms.desc: Date of the valuation of financial statements

terms.name: Credit Situation
terms.desc: Credit Situation: Up to date (N), (I30) Irregular 1-30; (I60) Irregular 30- 60; (I90) Irregular 60 - 90, Dudoso Especial (DNP), Total Arrears > 90D(MORA) (M), Pre-Litigation (P), Litigation (C))

terms.name: Economic Sector
terms.desc: Economic sector according to the Bank of Spain clasification, also referred in the Plan Limits. Inventory attached

terms.name: Local Rating
terms.desc: Customer clasification for provisioning, according to the central banks of each country

terms.name: Substandard
terms.desc: Flag indicating whether the customert is classified as substandard. (S) substandard; (N) Non substandard.

terms.name: Substandard Date
terms.desc: Date indicating when the customer is classified as substandard

terms.name: Non-standarized
terms.desc: Flag indicating whether the customer is non-standarized (S) non-standarized (N) in other case.

terms.name: Irregular Situation Date
terms.desc: Starting date of the operation in irregular situation, if the customer has several operations will be included  the earliest date

terms.name: Doubtful Date
terms.desc: Date indicating when the customer has any operation as doubtful. If there are several operations will be included  the earliest date

terms.name: Regulatory Capital due to Internal  advanced method (Credit R)
terms.desc: Regulatory Capital due to Internal  advanced method (Credit R)

terms.name: BASIC PORTFOLIO
terms.desc: Minimum level of aggregation. We assume that from this level, we need calculate the metrics at higher levels.Generally, the basic portfolio will be the level that the units will report. Additionally, for companies treated with a portfolio basis, the information reported to the Group will be at contract level.The aggregation levels for reporting are: client (for TOP list) and aggregation of basic portfolios (Group, Country, Unit, Entity, Business Line, Segment, Product, Forbearances, etc).The 'Sector' attribute is not consideres as mandatory but recommended.In case of changes in the definition of Basic Portfolio, some of its axis might happen to be considered as a new dimension. See functional document of Basic Porfolio's definition.In case of not having the data at the date requested, the last available data will be used.Concerning Structural Risks, 'Basic Portfolio' allows the segregation of 'Net REC' into 'Sovereign Risk Open_date' and 'Intragroup Risk Open_date'.

terms.name: SUBJECTIVE NPL
terms.desc: Subjective NPL, is a subjective classification of the risks (assets & contingent liabilities). In these cases, while the loan may only be impaired or even current in payment, there are reasonable doubts as to whether the customer will make full payment of the capital and interest under the contractual terms. These customers are assessed on a case-by-case basis using the expert criteria of the analyst/manager, and are considered by a decision-making body (in accordance with the Credit Risk Management Policy Manual).Classification as subjective NPL affects all the customer's transactions In the terminology of Bank of Spain Circular 4/04, this relates to 'Doubtful for reasons other than counterparty arrears'.

terms.name: COST OF CREDIT
terms.desc: This comprises all the debt instruments and contingent liabilities that, while not meeting the criteria to be classified individually as non-performing or as write-offs, present weaknesses that may cause the entity to assume losses exceeding the coverage for impairment of the risks under special monitoring.We make a distinction between:-Bank of Spain, all substandard risks proposed by the Bank of Spain following an analysis of the customers and under a direct mandate by this body.-Internal classification: all substandard risks proposed mainly by the Risk/Recovery Business Area and/or Internal Audit.-Forbearance: all substandard risks that are in certain phases of the cure periods in ex-post forbearance or during the grace periods

terms.name: PORTFOLIO WEIGHTED AVERAGE TENOR
terms.desc: Weighted average maturity of the remaining amount of the cash flows that the borrower is contractually obliged to pay during the period. It is calculated using the following formula:M=MAX (MIN{?t{t*CFt/?tCF_t)This is calculated for each contract, and then in order to obtain the average, it must be weighted by economic EAD.It differs from the C.GGS.CP.00295 measure (REGULATORY MATURITY), in that neither maximum nor minimum amounts are applied. Also, the economic EAD is used instead of regulatory EAD.

terms.name: Provision
terms.desc: Provision amount according to Circ 4/04 of the customer.  In thousands of local currency units

terms.name: Local Provision
terms.desc: Local provision amount according to Circ 4/04 of the customer.  In thousands of local currency units

terms.name: EARLY ARREARS PORTFOLIO
terms.desc: Position or Balance of the transactions, irrespective of the holder or guarantee, that have any amount past due on the principal, interest or contractually agreed expenses, provided that they have not yet been classified as non-performing.

terms.name: GROSS BASIC MARGIN FROM CREDIT (GBMC)
terms.desc: The sum of the Net Interest Income and the Non-Financial Fees and Commission Income for the Credit products

terms.name: HISTORIC_RORAC
terms.desc: It is defined as the risk-adjusted return that is obtained as the quotient between the result and the capital that a transaction,  client or any aggragation axis has associated. The historic RORAC is used to calculate the relationship between the risk and return of the portfolio transactions over a 12 month period.

terms.name: TOTAL ARREARS > 90D (MORA)
terms.desc: Position or Balance of transactions with amounts more than 90 days past due, unless they have been classified as written-off. Where there are stricter local criteria at certain Units, the more conservative criteria will be included for transactions in arrears.In the terminology of Bank of Spain Circular 4/04, this relates to 'Doubtful due to counterparty arrears', except those which are classified as Pre-Litigation or Litigation (see definition in this document). The sum of this metric and the positions in Pre-Litigation and Litigation is the total Doubtful or Non-performing Loans (according to the Bank of Spain definition)

terms.name: NEW PRODUCTION/STOCK/TOTAL PORTFOLIO/AMORTIZATION OF NEW PRODUCTION
terms.desc: New Production: This will comprise the new transactions and renewals with changes to terms and conditions not caused by financial difficulties arranged since a particular date, normally from the beginning of the month in progress, until a specific date. All the gross transactions will be taken into consideration, without taking into account the repayments on these transactions or renewals. Forbearance transactions are not classified as new production.In the reports, it will comprise the new transactions and renewals with increased limits arranged since 1 January of the year in progress until the date on which the report is produced.For Standardised Risks, new production will comprise the transactions arising from the decision events, Acceptance Pre-Approved and Acceptance Not Pre-Approved, formalised in the budget period.In the senior management report, if the information is presented on a quarterly basis, the New Production of the corresponding three months will be shown, without taking the previous three months into account. If it is the first or second month of the quarter, the information for one or two months, respectively, will be shown, without taking the new production of the previous quarters into account. For example, in the case of June, the first quarter will comprise the New Production for January, February and March, and the second quarter will comprise the New Production for April, May and June, without taking the New Production of the previous quarter into account.Stock: This comprises all the transactions with balances not yet paid, because either they have not yet reached their maturity date or, having done so, there are still payment obligations that have not been met, except the transactions arranged as new production. Therefore, all transactions made on the stock will be included in this section. Forbearance transactions will be included.Total Portfolio: it will include all the transactions defined for each metric independently of its credit status.Amortization of New Production: This will comprise those transactions from New Production which have been either totally or partially amortized during the current period.In the reports, it will comprise the amortizations formalized from the 1st of January of the current year up to the date in which the report is made.

terms.name: Rating
terms.desc: Internal assessment of the credit quality of a customer based on corporate methodology

terms.name: WEIGHTED AVERAGE RATING
terms.desc: Average internal rating weighted by Drawn Open_date

terms.name: CREDIT STATUS
terms.desc: Up to date: This is a classification of customer default risk established by the Bank of Spain in its Circular 4/04. It is defined as the balance of the debt instruments and contingent liabilities that do not meet the requirements to be classified in the following categories: substandard, doubtful due to counterparty arrears, doubtful for reasons other than counterparty arrears, or write-offs.Within this category, it will be necessary to identify the transactions that require special monitoring, which are understood to be those presenting weaknesses which, while not requiring higher coverage than those established for the standard risk transactions, make special monitoring by the entity advisable. The transactions that must be identified as under special monitoring will include, until their extinction, the following:- refinancing, refinanced or restructured transactions; - as well as those relating to customers declared to be in insolvency proceedings that have been reclassified from one of the doubtful loan categories as they met the requirements set forth therein; and- the transactions classified as standard of customers that have one or more transactions classified as doubtful due to counterparty arrears. Despite the foregoing, the refinancing, refinanced and restructured transactions will cease to be identified as under special monitoring when it has finished. This will occur after an exhaustive review of their equity and financial situation, where the holders will not foreseeably be in financial difficulty and, therefore, may meet the payment of the debt (principal and interest) of all their transactions at the entity in due time and form and, moreover, provided that they have settled the principal and interest payments accrued from the date on which the restructuring or refinancing transaction was arranged, where at least two years have elapsed since that date, where the principal of the transaction has been reduced by, at least, 20%, and where the customers have paid all the amounts (principal and interest) that were unpaid at the date of the restructuring or refinancing transaction.The Special Watch classification is a regulatory requirement and is a different concept to the Special Monitoring portfolios (see definition of FEVE contained in this document). Substandard Risk: This is a classification of customer default risk established by the Bank of Spain in its Circular 4/04. It is defined as the balance of the debt instruments and contingent liabilities that, while not meeting the criteria to be classified individually as doubtful or as write-offs, present weaknesses that may cause the entity to assume losses exceeding the coverage for impairment of the risks under special monitoring. This category includes: the transactions of customers forming part of groups in difficulties, for which overall losses are estimated that exceed those relating to the categories described in the foregoing points, and transactions not documented adequately.Furthermore, in accordance with the Corporate Policy for Debt Forbearance, the following would be classified as substandard:- Transactions classified as doubtful may be reclassified to substandard once three months of payment have elapsed (not including grace periods), provided that, during the period of the new payments of the transaction, all the amounts (principal and ordinary interest) that were unpaid at the date of forbearance are paid, and that there is reasonable certainty that the customer is able to meet the payments according to the repayment schedule.- If a grace period has been established, the forbearance will be reclassified as substandard risk, provided that it has not already been classified as doubtful risk. This classification must continue until three monthly payments (or equivalent) have been paid after the grace period has finished.- If a forbearance transaction becomes impaired, this will be regarded as sufficient cause to classify it as substandard risk:o Where, after the forbearance, a non-technical impairment situation arises, it will be classified as substandard risk, provided that this impairment denotes an overstatement of the estimated payment capacity on analysing the viability of the forbearance.o A situation may not be considered to be technically impaired where the customer continues in an impairment situation for more than 30 days or where the impaired amount is higher than a repayment amount.DNPA: DNPA meaning 'Doubtful, Not Pre-Action', is a subjective classification of the risks. In these cases, while the loan may only be in arrears or even current in payment, there are reasonable doubts as to whether the customer will make full payment of the capital and interest under the contractual terms. These customers are assessed on a case-by-case basis using the expert criteria of the analyst/manager, and are considered by a decision-making body (in accordance with the Credit Risk Management Policy Manual).Classification as DNPA affects all the customer's transactions Simple Default: This is the balance of transactions with amounts more than 90 days past due, unless they have been classified as written-off. Where there are stricter local criteria at certain Units, the more conservative criteria will be included for transactions in arrears.In the terminology of Bank of Spain Circular 4/04, this relates to 'Doubtful due to counterparty arrears', except that which is classified as Pre-Action Portfolio or Portfolio at Procedural Stage (see definition in this document). The sum of Simple Default and the positions in Pre-Action Portfolio and Portfolio at Procedural Stage is the total Doubtful Due to Counterparty Arrears (according to the Bank of Spain definition)Pre-Action: This category contains the positions of customers about whom there are sufficient doubts as to the possibility of repayment. This is normally the situation prior to initiating legal action.Procedural: In this situation, a court claim is made on the debt. The out-of-court process is managed with the customer by the Recovery Manager and/or through the lawyer representing us. The portfolio at procedural stage should also take into consideration customers in bankruptcy proceedings. This circumstance should not entail abandoning direct negotiations with the debtor. Therefore, the Portfolio at Procedural Stage will only include the balances of loans claimed using legal action that are not current in payment and that are non-performing. The other balances of transactions claimed using legal action that are current in payment will be included in the DNPA PortfolioWrite-offs: The balance of the customers written off or down according to the timetable (pursuant to the regulator's rules) or as a result of an internal decision where appropriate, which have been derecognised. Classification in this category does not imply that the entity will interrupt negotiations and legal actions to recover the amount owedTotal Portfolio: It will include all the transactions defined for each measure, regardless of their credit situation.

terms.name: 2ND OR MORE FORBEARANCE
terms.desc: The total of transactions forborne twice or more is the sum of the balance of all the transactions forborne more than once.

terms.name: % 2ND AND SUCCESSIVE FORBEARANCE TRANSACTIONS (STOCK)
terms.desc: Total Balance of 2nd Forbearance/Total Balance of Forbearance

terms.name: NPL ENTRIES/ECONOMIC EAD
terms.desc: New NPLs for the period divided by the Economic EAD (Open_date) for the period

terms.name: STOCK OF FORBORNE LOAN PORTFOLIO
terms.desc: Under the general term of debt forbearance, the term used for this corporate policy, we refer to the transactions in which there is evidence of current or future financial difficulty on the part of the customers to meet their payment obligations to the Santander Group in the current contractual terms. Therefore, it is necessary to amend, cancel the transaction and/or arrange a new one.Total forbearance is the sum of the balance of all the forbearance transactions.

terms.name: WEIGHT OF THE HIGH-RISK PROFILE (HRP) PORTFOLIO IN THE PORTFOLIO AS A WHOLE
terms.desc: This expresses the percentage of Total Drawn Open_date represented by the High-Risk Profile (HRP) portfolios, based on the Risk premium criteria. This metric will be calculated at the Unit or Group level, depending on the scope of the report.

terms.name: WEIGHT OF THE HIGH-RISK PROFILE (HRP) PORTFOLIO IN THE TOTAL INDIVIDUALS PORTFOLIO
terms.desc: This expresses the percentage of EAD of standardised portfolios represented by High-Risk Profile (HRP) standardised portfolios. Where EAD is not available, the Drawn Open_date will be used.

terms.name: MAXIMUM SECTOR CONCENTRATION OVER TOTAL PORTFOLIO
terms.desc: Ratio where the highest Drawn Open_date of all economic sectors is divided by the Total Drawn Open_date at Unit or Group level, depending on the scope of the report.

terms.name: MAXIMUM SECTOR CONCENTRATION OVER TOTAL PORTFOLIO EXCL. INDIVIDUALS
terms.desc: Ratio where the highest Drawn Open_date of all economic sectors is divided by the Total Drawn Open_date at Unit or Group level, excluding Individuals.

terms.name: % OF ECONOMIC EAD OF THE NEW PRODUCTION COVERED BY APPLICATION AND BEHAVIOUR MODELS
terms.desc: Ratio where the highest Drawn Open_date of all economic sectors is divided by the Total Drawn Open_date at Unit or Group level, excluding Individuals.

terms.name: New Production Covered by Application and Behaviour Models
terms.desc: New Production Covered by Application and Behaviour Models

terms.name: % ECONOMIC EAD COVERED BY RECOVERY MODELS
terms.desc: Ratio where the highest Drawn Open_date of all economic sectors is divided by the Total Drawn Open_date at Unit or Group level, excluding Individuals.

terms.name: Up to Date Portfolio (non NPL)
terms.desc: Position or Balance of all the contracts that do not present delays in payment.

terms.name: IRREGULAR 1-30
terms.desc: Position or Balance of the impaired portfolio within the period beginning on the first day of default and ending 30 days thereafter, both inclusive. Therefore, if the first unpaid amount falls due on day five, this period lasts until the end of day 5 of the following month.It is also known as I30

terms.name: IRREGULAR 31-60
terms.desc: Position or Balance of the impaired portfolio within the period beginning one month and one day after the first day of default and ending a further month thereafter, both inclusive. Therefore, if the unpaid amount falls due on day 5, this period lasts until the end of day 5 (two months thereafter)It is also called I60

terms.name: IRREGULAR 61-90
terms.desc: Position or Balance of the impaired portfolio within the period beginning two months and one day after the first day of default and ending a further month thereafter, both inclusive. Therefore, if the unpaid amount falls due on day 5, this period lasts until the end of day 5 (three months thereafter)It is also called I90

terms.name: HIGH-RISK PROFILE PORTFOLIO (HRP PORTFOLIO)
terms.desc: A portfolio will be considered as high risk if the Risk premium exceeds 13%. The final result will be a 'YES' or 'NO' comment to identify if the Basic Portfolio or an aggregate of Basis Portfolios is a HRP Portfolio.

terms.name: Entries to Forbearance Portfolio Ex Ante
terms.desc: Restructures to loans that are up to date or delinquent (<90dpd) done during this period

terms.name: Entries to Forbearance Portfolio Ex Post
terms.desc: Restructures to loans classified as doubtful/NPL (>90dpd and subjective NPL) done during this period

terms.name: FORBEARANCE FLOW
terms.desc: This is the total ex-ante and ex-post forbearance transactions in a period

terms.name: CET1 (BIS III) RATIO MAXIMUM IMPACT
terms.desc: This expresses the maximum impact (in bp) on capital that the Group assumes it could tolerate, arising from a stress in the value of government debt and in the structural FX position. The Capital ratio to be used depends on each Unit:  CET1 for the Group and BIS III Units, CORE CAPITAL for BIS II Units and TIER 1 for BIS I Units.This metric is calculated by Market Risk team and Methodology for Group calculations. It includes the impact on Capital Base and RWA (numerator and denominator).It is applicable to the Total Group or Total Unit.

terms.name: % +60 DAYS ARREARS OVER TOTAL ARREARS PORTFOLIO
terms.desc: Ratio where the balance of 61-90 days Arrears is divided by the stock of 1-90 days Arrears

terms.name: Substandard Allowances
terms.desc: All the allowances assigned to the substandard portfolio in accordance with Circular 4/2004.

terms.name: % Economic EAD Covered by Recovery Models
terms.desc: % Economic EAD Covered by Recovery Models

terms.name: NUMBER OF ECONOMIC GROUPS  RATING UNDER 5.0
terms.desc: NUMBER OF ECONOMIC GROUPS  RATING UNDER 5.0
